messages: ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:11): K^Holtz, let it dry a lot longer
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:12): remove the drive if you want to try and preserve what's on it
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:14): grandrew, privet
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:29): Do hard disks have a USB cable port too???
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:29): mine doesn't hav
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:30): no. you can obtain ide/usb adapters, though.
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:30): and I read here ( http://uk.answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=1006050802018 ) that its not possible to connect an old hard disk (with no USB) to a laptop
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:31): its that easy?
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:31): any hard-disk will work?
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:31): (and what about the power)
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:31): any 3.5" hard drive ought to work with a ide/usb adapter intended for 3.5" drives.
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:31): laptops use 2.5" hard drives.
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:32): unless the adapter is part of an enclosure intended to power the drive as well, just use the molex
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:34): the plastic power connector.
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:35): which can be taken from a desktop
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:36): why would you want to hook your hard drive to a usb port, though?
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:37): to transfer the data
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:37): (and to take back-ups)
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:40): -> supposedly this one supplies power as well. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000A0O1D2/sr=8-2/qid=1152084837/ref=pd_bbs_2/104-0557789-8824710?ie=UTF8
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:41): but that is generally the kind of kit you would need.
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:45): look at this : http://www.the-gadgeteer.com/review/usb_2_0_to_ide_cable_version_2
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:46): it has two plugs, for 2.5 inch notebook drive and for the 3.5 inch desktop drive
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:46): what's the difference in both?
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:48): (btw, I wish there were such a connector for AGP / PCI-Express to USB 2.0 !!!! Then we could connect a graphic card to a laptop.)
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:48): 2.5" drive uses a smaller plug
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:50): then why does it have two?
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:50): the one shown here: http://www.the-gadgeteer.com/review/usb_2_0_to_ide_cable_version_2
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:50): one for larger 3.5" drives
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:50): and a second, smaller one for 2.5" notebook drives
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:52): derek[], AGP/PCI-E are much faster than other buses for good reason... USB2 does not have enough bandwidth to run serious video...
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:52): maybe there is a 1394-AGP adapter out there
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:53): bjv, sorry, I read "smaller" as "same" :S
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:53): brick, what for?
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:53): what what?
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:53): brick maybe there is a 1394-AGP adapter out there
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:54): <derek[]> (btw, I wish there were such a connector for AGP / PCI-Express to USB 2.0 !!!! Then we could connect a graphic card to a laptop.)
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:54): it would still need an external power supply... not the best solution
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:54): and AGP card needs a separate power supply?
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (12:55): firewire and USB don't carry the voltages or currents needed for a serious video card
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (12:55): modern cards can suck power.
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (12:56): ok may be a little low quality graphic card could be made that could be used in the type II (or III) slot
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:03): http://images.tigerdirect.com/SKUimages/medium/T13-1072-main.jpg monitor power pass through? coolmax, what is this 1993?
c72dbdf529e69c1ae3fed7f262edaa92 (13:04): no they have a usb video card
c72dbdf529e69c1ae3fed7f262edaa92 (13:04): but it's 2d only and even then somewhat limited
c72dbdf529e69c1ae3fed7f262edaa92 (13:04): anyways goodnight
ae2723c5c3c9da84b0c32669c7b01e60 (13:05): bjv, the only problem i have with that idea is that you need that other kind of cable...
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (13:08): my monitor has two cables
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (13:08): one goes into that power socket
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:19): bjv: the worst thing about ATX by far is that the PSUs couldn't shut a connected monitor off with the computer
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:20): a 'sleeping' modern monitor consumes like 0 watts
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:21): bjv: a monitor cut off at the pwer consumes *EXACTLY* 0 watts
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:21): admittedly that tiny winking green eye does drive me bonkers.
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:21): besides, it's an absolute pain to have to use 2 power outlets for the one PC
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:22): derek[]: they make perpetually self-powered ones no? ;)
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (13:23): self-powered o.o?
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:23): derek[]: he hasn't been following the conversation ;)
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:24): derek[]: LCDs don't solve the problem of needing two power outlets for one PC
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (13:24): bjv a 'sleeping' modern monitor consumes like 0 watts
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (13:24): well I thought that was the issue
c7a0f7f681d241bad1095b1898691e52 (13:24): saving power
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:24): phhh. you only need a 2nd outlet if you are a little baby, who needs to ~monitor what his machine is doing.
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:25): bjv: if powersupplies still had pass-through power on them you wouldn't need a second outlet for that, either ;)

46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:28): I wonder, with both Intel and AMD targeting much lower power consumption with their new desktop chips will you be able to get away with a smaller PSU than you need now?
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:29): i would be amazed if most people used more then 160w
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:30): well. i guess Dell has been hard and work ensuring a netburst pentium in every kettle.
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:30): if they had real processors though. 1 hard disk, onboard graphics and a dvd burner you never use doesnt suck much juice.

46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:31): I have a 300W atm and it seems to be coping with a 3000+ Athlon XP, a 9500 Pro, a hard drive and two optical drives. I was looking at having to replace it if I went Athlon 64/PCI-E Radeon but I'm all but settled on the Core 2 Duo now so I'm wodering if I'd be able to get away with the 300 again
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:34): i will say that pentium-d 940 and a 7900gt look very nice together.
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:34): the 4400 is just too expensive.
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:36): I wouldn't buy a netburst derivative, I'm only considering going back to an Intel-based rig because they've canned the crappy netburst architecture
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:38): yonah isnt 64bit, though. is it?
d7ebcea89344cbd73c07eb41f58b3db0 (13:41): hmm, can you not get SATA-300 cards that are normal PCI - or is it too fast for PCI?
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:41): PCI is too fast for normal SATA, SATA300 is a pipedream
d7ebcea89344cbd73c07eb41f58b3db0 (13:42): PCI is too fast?
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:42): solid state sata/300 drives?
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:42): bjv: Yonah, the original Core Duo, isn't but I'm certain I read somewhere that Conroe, or Core 2 Duo, will have EM64T^WAMD64
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:43): yes. i wouldnt be surprised if next years chip had 64bit support, finally
d7ebcea89344cbd73c07eb41f58b3db0 (13:43): will an SATA-300 drive work on an SATA-150 controller? (obviously at lower speed)
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:44): meh, 64 bit is largely marketing hype
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (13:45): LSD`: maybe you can show me how to make .tar.bz2 larger then 2^32 bytes large?
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:46): bjv: sounds more like a filesystem limitation than the word size of the cpu
d7ebcea89344cbd73c07eb41f58b3db0 (13:48): derek[]: hi o.O
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:52): ItIt looks like it has a Silicon Image chip on it, that should work in Linux just fine
46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:52): SiI are cheap and nasty, but they get the job done
d7ebcea89344cbd73c07eb41f58b3db0 (13:53): mmm

46c5b3443eb7241f44943054d7f43491 (13:54): My motherboard has an SiI controller on it (a 3112) and it used to run Linux with no major dramas. Biggest problem I had with it was no realising GRUB called drives hd* regardless of whether they were PATA, SATA or whatever
